content:
âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: I had a good time !

Here is my solution in Ruby :

n = gets.to_i
items = Hash.new(0)
n.times {items[gets.chomp] += 1}

items.sort_by {|a,b| -b}.to_h.each do |item, count|
  puts "#{(count.to_f*100/n).round(1)}% #{item}"
end

1. Output "n" lines instead of "x" lines. Please also add a colon after "lines".

2. Tests and validators should be different.
Currently "Fruits" test and "Validator 2" are the same, and "Salsas" test and "Validator 1" are the same.

[[n] lines is the number of lines in the input, which is different from the number of lines required for the output.

Updated the validator.

I'm sure @5DN1L means:

Fruits TEST
Input
6
Apple
Banana
Apple
Carrot
Banana
Apple

Validator 2 VALIDATOR
Input
6
Apple
Banana
Apple
Carrot
Banana
Apple

are fully identical which is bad.

You could add some more carrots (Improve my eye-sight! ðŸ˜‚) and some pears (I love them! ðŸ˜‚) in the validator test and alter the output accordingly, e. g.

9
Apple
Carrot
Banana
Apple
Pear
Carrot
Banana
Pear
Apple
OK, understood the point about n and x. Guess it will be clearer if you add the definition of x there too, e.g. [[x]] being the number of unique items.

Yeah, I changed a few a little bit. I had a brainfart about how validators prevent hardcoding and thought switching them around is good enough. 
Thank you :)

Why are you not fixing test case Fruits and Validator 2?
They are identical too.
They are not, look more carefully lol

Carefully fixed them with minimal effort. :)

Would love if it you could import them from files or API, that'd make it a lot easier.
